\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{index::doc}}


\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics[width=400\sphinxpxdimen]{{login_screen}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Icy Board is a modern, memory\sphinxhyphen{}safe re\sphinxhyphen{}implementation of the classic
PCBoard Bulletin Board System.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Written in Rust—aiming to preserve the original experience while
enabling secure, scriptable expansion on today’s platforms
(Linux, macOS, Windows, ARM, etc.).

\sphinxAtStartPar
Unlike emulation layers that just “run the old EXE”,
Icy Board rebuilds core subsystems:
user base, conferences, message storage (JAM),
time/byte bank, accounting scaffolding, PPL execution, and TUI
administration—providing a foundation that is both compatible \sphinxstyleemphasis{and}
extensible.


\chapter{Icy Board}
\label{\detokenize{index:icy-board}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Due to its inheritance of PCBoard’s architecture, Icy Board aims to
provide a familiar experience for long\sphinxhyphen{}time users while introducing
modern features and improvements.


\section{Key Goals}
\label{\detokenize{index:key-goals}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
High compatibility with PCBoard 15.4 behaviors and PPE ecosystem

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Safe modernization: UTF\sphinxhyphen{}8, Internet protocols (Telnet, SSH, WebSockets)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Preserve PCB / ANSI / Avatar / RIP aesthetics (nostalgia intact)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Provide a fully featured PPL toolchain (compile, decompile, LSP)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Make migration of legacy installations feasible

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Extend with new objects / APIs \sphinxstyleemphasis{without} breaking old PPE plugins

\end{itemize}


\section{Non\sphinxhyphen{}Goals (by design)}
\label{\detokenize{index:non-goals-by-design}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} \begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{“One\sphinxhyphen{}click shiny” out\sphinxhyphen{}of\sphinxhyphen{}box board—historical complexity retained}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
PCBoard was never simple; neither is IcyBoard

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Heavy GUI configuration (focus is terminal / SSH TUIs)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Running on DOS / Windows 9x / OS/2

\end{itemize}


\section{License}
\label{\detokenize{index:license}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Dual\sphinxhyphen{}licensed (Apache 2.0 / MIT) — see repository LICENSE files.


\section{Building}
\label{\detokenize{index:building}}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Prerequisites:}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Rust toolchain (stable) — \sphinxurl{https://www.rust-lang.org/tools/install}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
A UTF\sphinxhyphen{}8 capable terminal (most modern terminals)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
(Optional) VS Code for PPL editing

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Build everything:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
git\PYG{+w}{ }clone\PYG{+w}{ }https://github.com/mkrueger/icy\PYGZus{}board.git
\PYG{n+nb}{cd}\PYG{+w}{ }icy\PYGZus{}board
cargo\PYG{+w}{ }build\PYG{+w}{ }\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}release
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
This will create a target/release/ directory with all executables.


\section{Getting started}
\label{\detokenize{index:getting-started}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
I recommend putting the bin/ directory in the path but you can just \sphinxtitleref{cd bin} for now.

\sphinxAtStartPar
First create a new BBS: \sphinxtitleref{./icbsetup create FOO}
Then start it: \sphinxtitleref{./icboard FOO}

\sphinxAtStartPar
This will fire up a new call waiting screen where you can log in as sysop. By defaulut telnet is enabled on port 1337.

\sphinxAtStartPar
NOTE: Ensure that your terminal screen is big enough \sphinxhyphen{} 80x25 at least.


\section{Tools}
\label{\detokenize{index:tools}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Icy Board includes a comprehensive suite of tools for BBS management and development:

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Core Executables}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{icboard}} \sphinxhyphen{} The main BBS server daemon

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{icbsetup}} \sphinxhyphen{} Terminal\sphinxhyphen{}based configuration and setup utility

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pplc}} \sphinxhyphen{} PPL compiler (source \(\rightarrow\) PPE)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ppld}} \sphinxhyphen{} PPL decompiler (PPE \(\rightarrow\) source)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{mkicbtxt}} \sphinxhyphen{} Create/Edit ICBTXT files containing all strings used.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{icbsysmgr}} \sphinxhyphen{} System manager utility (user/group editor)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ppl\sphinxhyphen{}language\sphinxhyphen{}server}} \sphinxhyphen{} Language server for PPL (for IDE integration)

\end{itemize}


\section{Directory Layout}
\label{\detokenize{index:directory-layout}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
I tried to simplify the PCBoard system a bit but it has limits.

\sphinxAtStartPar
A typical Icy Board installation follows this structure:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
FOO/                    \PYGZsh{} Your BBS root (created by icbsetup)
├── icboard.toml        \PYGZsh{} Main configuration file
├── icboard.log         \PYGZsh{} Runtime log file
├── users.toml          \PYGZsh{} User database
├── art/                \PYGZsh{} Graphics and art files
│   └── help/           \PYGZsh{} Help Files
├── main/               \PYGZsh{} Main board files
├── conferences/        \PYGZsh{} Conference data
└── tmp/                \PYGZsh{} Generated Files for backwards compatibility
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\label{\detokenize{index:main-files}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{main/}} directory contains core system configuration and data files:

\section{art/ files}
\label{\detokenize{index:art-files}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
It’s recommended to use .pcb, .ans, .rip, .asc extensions instead of the old …G, …R sheme.
This makes it easier to draw files with an ansi
drawing tool as well. And file name lengths ar no longer an issue.
Files can either be CP437 or UTF\sphinxhyphen{}8 \sphinxhyphen{} IcyBoard will do
all conversions automatically. Note that UTF\sphinxhyphen{}8 requires the UTF\sphinxhyphen{}8 BOM.
This is by design it’s the only way to make a
fast and correct decision about the file encoding.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Note: UTF\sphinxhyphen{}8 is recommended for everything.


\section{icbsetup}
\label{\detokenize{index:icbsetup}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxtitleref{icbsetup} is the interactive TUI (text user interface) utility
used to create, configure and maintain an Icy Board installation.

\sphinxAtStartPar
It’s more than the classic PCBoard PCBSETUP untility.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Create new BBS installations

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Import legacy PCBoard systems

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Help converting PPE plugins to modern systems

\end{itemize}


\section{Create new BBS installations}
\label{\detokenize{index:create-new-bbs-installations}}\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Pick an identifier (letters / digits / underscore). Example: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{FOO}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Create the instance:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
./icbsetup\PYG{+w}{ }create\PYG{+w}{ }FOO
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Start it:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
./icboard\PYG{+w}{ }FOO
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\end{enumerate}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Then the call waiting screen appears. You can access the setup or log in as user or sysop.


\section{Import legacy PCBoard systems}
\label{\detokenize{index:import-legacy-pcboard-systems}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Icy Board can ingest an existing PCBoard installation directly from your original
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{PCBOARD.DAT}} (plus the related files it references). The importer converts
binary/text formats into structured TOML, normalizes encodings to UTF\sphinxhyphen{}8 (with BOM
for display files), hashes passwords, and recreates conferences, commands,
security levels, protocols, colors, text resources, and user base metadata.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
./icbsetup\PYG{+w}{ }import\PYG{+w}{ }/path/to/pcb\PYG{+w}{ }/path/to/NEW\PYGZus{}BBS\PYGZus{}DIR
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
On success:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Converted files populate \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NEW\_BBS\_DIR/}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
A log file is written to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NEW\_BBS\_DIR/importlog.txt}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
You can start the board:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
./icboard\PYG{+w}{ }/path/to/NEW\PYGZus{}BBS\PYGZus{}DIR
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Limitations are that the importer may import wrong/old paths \sphinxhyphen{} they may need to be manually adjusted.
PPE plugins need to be manually converted as well.


\section{Post\sphinxhyphen{}import tasks}
\label{\detokenize{index:post-import-tasks}}\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
See \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{importlog.txt}} for warnings/errors (missing files, malformed records).

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Manual convert PPE plugins (see below).

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Test a migrated user:
* Login
* Read mail/conferences
* Post a test message

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Enable network services (telnet/ssh) only after verifying console launch works.

\end{enumerate}


\section{Converting PPE plugins to modern systems}
\label{\detokenize{index:converting-ppe-plugins-to-modern-systems}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Even if .PPE files don’t need to be recompiled (they may work as\sphinxhyphen{}is) they may need to be adjusted to work with Icy Board.
Most of them have a configuration that hint to old paths or files that don’t exist anymore. So they need to be manually adjusted.

\sphinxAtStartPar
I recommend lowercasing all filenames and paths \sphinxhyphen{} Icy Board is case\sphinxhyphen{}sensitive as well as converting all text files to UTF\sphinxhyphen{}8 with BOM.

\sphinxAtStartPar
WARNING: Backup your original PPE files before conversion!

\sphinxAtStartPar
For that icbsetup has a PPE conversion assistant:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
./icbsetup\PYG{+w}{ }ppe\PYGZhy{}convert\PYG{+w}{ }/path/to/ppe
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
This will lowercase all files and convert most fils from CP437 to UTF\sphinxhyphen{}8 with BOM. If a file is CP437 and is not converted.
(This is likely the case because there are plenty of text files with strange extensions).

\sphinxAtStartPar
Manual convert a single file with

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
./icbsetup\PYG{+w}{ }ppe\PYGZhy{}convert\PYG{+w}{ }/path/to/file.nfo
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
This will convert a single CP437 file to UTF\sphinxhyphen{}8 with BOM. The PPE engine will automatically detect the encoding and convert to CP437 if needed.

\sphinxstepscope


\subsection{Introduction to PPL}
\label{\detokenize{ppl:introduction-to-ppl}}\label{\detokenize{ppl::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
PPL (PCBoard Programming Language) is the classic scripting language
used to extend and customize the PCBoard Bulletin Board System.
Icy Board ships with a modern, memory\sphinxhyphen{}safe, fully reimplemented PPL toolchain:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
A virtual machine (runtime) executing PPE (compiled PPL) modules

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
A modern, stricter compiler: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pplc}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
A robust decompiler: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ppld}} (recovers structure from legacy PPEs)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
A Language Server (LSP) + VS Code extension for syntax help, hovers, navigation

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Extended language versions introducing optional new syntax and data types

\end{itemize}


\subsubsection{Core Goals}
\label{\detokenize{ppl:core-goals}}\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
High compatibility with PCBoard PPEs up to 15.4 (run, decompile, recompile)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Safe modernization (UTF\sphinxhyphen{}8 source, stricter diagnostics, secure password handling)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Progressive evolution (optional newer \sphinxstyleemphasis{language versions} that do not break older scripts unless you opt in)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Better tooling (warnings instead of silent miscompiles; IDE support; disassembly view)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Eliminate “anti\sphinxhyphen{}decompile” era tricks—make maintenance possible again

\end{enumerate}


\subsubsection{Vocabulary: Runtime vs Language Version}
\label{\detokenize{ppl:vocabulary-runtime-vs-language-version}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
You will see two related version notions:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Runtime / PPE format version}: The bytecode / PPE container format (100\sphinxhyphen{}400).

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Language version}: The surface syntax \& feature set you target.
By default language version = runtime version unless overridden (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}lang\sphinxhyphen{}version}}).

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
You can (for example) generate a PPE in runtime format 400 but restrict yourself
to language features of 340 to stay compatible with older boards (where applicable).


\subsubsection{Toolchain Overview}
\label{\detokenize{ppl:toolchain-overview}}

\begin{savenotes}\sphinxattablestart
\sphinxthistablewithglobalstyle
\centering
\begin{tabulary}{\linewidth}[t]{TT}
\sphinxtoprule
\sphinxstyletheadfamily 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Tool
&\sphinxstyletheadfamily 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Purpose
\\
\sphinxmidrule
\sphinxtableatstartofbodyhook
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxtitleref{pplc}
\sphinxtitleref{ppld}
LSP
Disasm
&
\sphinxAtStartPar
Compile \sphinxtitleref{.pps} (UTF\sphinxhyphen{}8 or CP437) into a PPE (PCBoard Exec)
Decompile an existing PPE back to readable PPL
Editor services: outline, hover help, go\sphinxhyphen{}to, completion
Optional internal view of low\sphinxhyphen{}level instructions
\\
\sphinxbottomrule
\end{tabulary}
\sphinxtableafterendhook\par
\sphinxattableend\end{savenotes}


\subsubsection{\sphinxstyleliteralintitle{\sphinxupquote{ppld}} \sphinxhyphen{} The Decompiler}
\label{\detokenize{ppl:ppld-the-decompiler}}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
ppld\PYG{+w}{ }hello.ppe
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Produces \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{hello.ppd}} plus (optionally) a reconstructed control structure
instead of flat GOTO spaghetti. Use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}d}} to view a disassembly and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}r}} for
a minimal (raw) form.


\subsubsection{Encoding \& Character Set}
\label{\detokenize{ppl:encoding-character-set}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Preferred input}: UTF\sphinxhyphen{}8 (modern editors)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Legacy}: Original DOS sources were CP437. Use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}cp437}} if auto\sphinxhyphen{}detection fails.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Compiler outputs CP437 in the PPE so legacy display semantics match PCBoard expectations.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
You may convert existing PPE data files to UTF\sphinxhyphen{}8 with: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{icbsetup ppe\sphinxhyphen{}convert \textless{}PATH\textgreater{}}} (make backups first).

\end{itemize}


\subsubsection{Key Differences vs Legacy PPLC (Summary)}
\label{\detokenize{ppl:key-differences-vs-legacy-pplc-summary}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
(See the detailed “PPL differences” section in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ppl.md}} for the full list.)
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Reserved words: a larger set is now treated as keywords (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{IF}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{FOR}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{CONTINUE}}, etc.) to prevent ambiguous parses.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Stricter: mismatched function return declarations are \sphinxstylestrong{errors} instead of silently ignored.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Additional identifier support (e.g. UTF\sphinxhyphen{}8 cases, the Euro sign).

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Cleaner loop constructs / assignment operators in higher language versions.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
DECLARE blocks no longer required in newer versions (\&gt;= 350).

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
More (and safer) warnings for suspicious code; treat warnings seriously when porting.

\end{itemize}


\subsubsection{Evolution by Language Version}
\label{\detokenize{ppl:evolution-by-language-version}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{\&lt;= 340}: Classic era; close to PCBoard 15.4 semantics.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{350} (PPL 4.0 modernization stage 1):
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
New loop forms: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{%
\PYG{k}{REPEAT} \PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.} \PYG{k}{UNTIL}%
}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{%
\PYG{k}{LOOP} \PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.} \PYG{k}{ENDLOOP}%
}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Assignment operators (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{%
\PYG{o}{+=} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}=} \PYG{o}{*=} \PYG{o}{/=} \PYG{o}{\PYGZpc{}=} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}=}%
}}, etc.)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Inline \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{%
\PYG{k}{RETURN} \PYG{n}{expr}%
}} (instead of assigning to function name)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Optional braces disambiguation improvements

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Variable initializers: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{%
\PYG{n}{TYPE} \PYG{n}{VAR} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{expr}%
}} or array initializer \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{%
\PYG{n}{TYPE} \PYG{n}{VAR} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}} \PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{b}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{c} \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}%
}}

\end{itemize}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{400} (In progress \textendash{} \sphinxstylestrong{experimental / subject to change}):
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Distinct usage of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{%
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{p}{]}%
}} for indexing, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{%
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}%
}} exclusively for array literals

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Emerging \sphinxstyleemphasis{object\sphinxhyphen{}style} access to BBS domain entities (e.g. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{%
\PYG{n}{CONFERENCE}%
}} objects, with member properties \& helper functions)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Overloadable predefined functions (e.g. dual \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{%
\PYG{n+nb}{CONFINFO}%
}} forms)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Goal: reduce need for manual file / config parsing in scripts

\end{itemize}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Use language gating to write compatible code:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c+cp}{;\PYGZdl{}IF}\PYG{c+cp}{ VERSION \PYGZlt{} 350}
    \PYG{n}{PRINTLN} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}Legacy path\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{c+cp}{;\PYGZdl{}ELSE}
    \PYG{n}{PRINTLN} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}Newer language features enabled\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{c+cp}{;\PYGZdl{}ENDIF}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsubsection{Preprocessor Summary}
\label{\detokenize{ppl:preprocessor-summary}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Directives (start with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{;\$}} on their own line):
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{%
\PYG{c+cp}{;\PYGZdl{}DEFINE}\PYG{c+cp}{ NAME[=VALUE]}%
}} \textendash{} define a symbol (value optional)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{%
\PYG{c+cp}{;\PYGZdl{}IF}\PYG{c+cp}{ expr}%
}} / \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{%
\PYG{c+cp}{;\PYGZdl{}ELIF}\PYG{c+cp}{ expr}%
}} / \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{%
\PYG{c+cp}{;\PYGZdl{}ELSE}%
}} / \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{%
\PYG{c+cp}{;\PYGZdl{}ENDIF}%
}} \textendash{} conditional compilation

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Token substitutions: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{%
\PYG{n+no}{;\PYGZsh{}Version}%
}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{%
\PYG{n+no}{;\PYGZsh{}Runtime}%
}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{%
\PYG{n+no}{;\PYGZsh{}LangVersion}%
}} expand to numeric values

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Simple example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{PRINTLN} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}Compiler Version:\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+no}{;\PYGZsh{}Version}
\PYG{c+cp}{;\PYGZdl{}IF}\PYG{c+cp}{ LANGVERSION \PYGZgt{}= 350}
    \PYG{n}{PRINTLN} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}Modern language features active.\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{c+cp}{;\PYGZdl{}ENDIF}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsubsection{Types \& Data Model (High Level)}
\label{\detokenize{ppl:types-data-model-high-level}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Scalars: Integer, Unsigned, Byte / Word, Boolean, Float, Double, Money, Date, Time

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Strings: Normal and “BigStr” (large string buffers)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Arrays: 1\textendash{}3 dimensional (indexed, zero\sphinxhyphen{}based internally)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Password values (internally hashed if Argon2 / BCrypt storage is enabled)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
(Planned / partial in 400) Domain objects: Conference, MessageArea, FileArea, with member\sphinxhyphen{}like accessors or function wrappers.

\end{itemize}


\subsubsection{Security \& Safety Notes}
\label{\detokenize{ppl:security-safety-notes}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Passwords: Hashing (Argon2 / BCrypt) is enforced by configuration; scripts that attempt to transform (uppercase/lowercase) hashed values should expect no\sphinxhyphen{}ops.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Avoid relying on internal hashes—display calls typically mask them.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
VM isolates runtime; catastrophic host crashes from buggy PPE logic are far harder now (memory safety from Rust).

\end{itemize}


\subsubsection{Migration Workflow (Legacy PPE \(\rightarrow\) Modern PPL)}
\label{\detokenize{ppl:migration-workflow-legacy-ppe-modern-ppl}}\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Decompile} legacy \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{FOO.PPE}} \(\rightarrow\) \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{FOO.PPS}} with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ppld}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Review warnings} when recompiling with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pplc}}; fix shadowed variables, questionable assignments, or deprecated idioms.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Decide language version}: If you need pure compatibility, stick to 340. If modern loops / returns help clarity, switch to 350.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Run under Icy Board}; validate interactive paths (menus, door launching, display).

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Iterate}: Use LSP tooling for rename, find references, and incremental modernization.

\end{enumerate}


\subsubsection{Disassembly for Learning}
\label{\detokenize{ppl:disassembly-for-learning}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Use:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
pplc\PYG{+w}{ }myscript.pps\PYG{+w}{ }\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}disassemble
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} or}
ppld\PYG{+w}{ }legacy.ppe\PYG{+w}{ }\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}disassemble
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
This produces a low\sphinxhyphen{}level opcode view. Helpful for verifying optimizer or diagnosing control\sphinxhyphen{}flow reconstruction.


\subsubsection{Quick Reference Cheat Card}
\label{\detokenize{ppl:quick-reference-cheat-card}}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
Compile:    pplc script.pps
Decompile:  ppld module.ppe
Disasm:     pplc script.pps \PYGZhy{}d
Encoding:   pplc \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}cp437 legacy.pps
Lang ver:   pplc script.pps \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}lang\PYGZhy{}version 350
PPE ver:    pplc script.pps \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}version 400
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{Developing PPL Applications}
\label{\detokenize{ppl:developing-ppl-applications}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Create \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{hello.pps}}:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
PRINTLN \PYGZdq{}Hello from Icy Board PPL!\PYGZdq{}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Compile:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
pplc\PYG{+w}{ }hello.pps
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Result: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{hello.ppe}}


\subsection{PCBoard Programming Language (PPL)}
\label{\detokenize{ppl:pcboard-programming-language-ppl}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This section enumerates all executable statement forms recognized by the modern Icy Board PPL compiler/VM.
Internal AST variants like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Block}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Empty}} are not user\sphinxhyphen{}written and are omitted.
\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Version legend:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
(100+)  Available since earliest supported baseline (classic PCB era).
(200+)  Introduced when SELECT/CASE became available.
(300+)  Introduced with DECLARE / FUNCTION / PROCEDURE formalization.
(350+)  Modernization wave (repeat/until, loop/endloop, inline return expr, compound assignments).

\end{description}


\subsubsection{Control Flow}
\label{\detokenize{ppl:control-flow}}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{IF single\sphinxhyphen{}line (100+)}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Syntax: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{%
\PYG{k}{IF} \PYG{p}{(} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{expr}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{statement}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}%
}}
Executes exactly one following statement if expression is TRUE (non\sphinxhyphen{}zero / non\sphinxhyphen{}empty). No ELSE on same line.

\sphinxlineitem{IF / THEN multi\sphinxhyphen{}line (100+)}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Syntax skeleton:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{IF} \PYG{p}{(} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{expr}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{p}{)} \PYG{n}{THEN}
    \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{statements}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{ELSEIF} \PYG{p}{(} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{expr}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{p}{)} \PYG{n}{THEN}
    \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{statements}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{o}{.}
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{ELSE}
    \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{statements}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{p}{]}
\PYG{n}{ENDIF}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Notes:}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Parentheses are required around the condition in modern forms.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{%
\PYG{k}{ELSEIF}%
}} chains are evaluated in order; first TRUE branch wins.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{%
\PYG{k}{ENDIF}%
}} terminator required.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\sphinxlineitem{SELECT / CASE (200+)}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Multi\sphinxhyphen{}way conditional.
Syntax:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{SELECT} \PYG{p}{(} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{expr}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{n}{CASE} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{const\PYGZus{}expr}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{const\PYGZus{}expr}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{statements}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}
    \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{CASE} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{const\PYGZus{}expr\PYGZus{}range\PYGZus{}or\PYGZus{}value\PYGZus{}list}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{statements}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{o}{.}
    \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{DEFAULT}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{statements}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{p}{]}
\PYG{n}{ENDSELECT}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Notes:}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Comparison is by value (string/integer/date/etc.) with standard PPL coercions.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Multiple values per CASE separated by commas.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Range syntax (e.g. 1..5) is supported where decompiler emits it.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{DEFAULT}} optional.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\sphinxlineitem{WHILE single\sphinxhyphen{}line (100+)}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Syntax: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{WHILE ( \textless{}expr\textgreater{} ) \textless{}statement\textgreater{}}}
Evaluates condition before each iteration; terminates when FALSE.

\sphinxlineitem{WHILE / ENDWHILE block (100+)}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Syntax:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{WHILE} \PYG{p}{(} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{expr}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{statements}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}
\PYG{n}{ENDWHILE}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxlineitem{DO WHILE style (WhileDo AST) (100+ legacy form)}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Some legacy PPEs decompile to a block starting with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{WHILE}} ending with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ENDWHILE}} (same as above).
The engine distinguishes single\sphinxhyphen{}line vs block internally; syntax to author is identical to “block” form.

\sphinxlineitem{REPEAT / UNTIL (350+)}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Post\sphinxhyphen{}condition loop (always executes body at least once).
Syntax:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{REPEAT}
    \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{statements}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}
\PYG{n}{UNTIL} \PYG{p}{(} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{expr}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Loop ends when expression becomes TRUE (reverse of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{WHILE}} semantics).

\sphinxlineitem{LOOP / ENDLOOP (350+)}
\sphinxAtStartPar
General loop for complex flows with manual BREAK/CONTINUE.
Syntax:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{LOOP}
    \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{statements}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}
\PYG{n}{ENDLOOP}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Equivalent to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{while TRUE}} with explicit termination via BREAK.

\sphinxlineitem{FOR / NEXT (100+)}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Counter iteration.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Syntax:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{FOR} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{identifier}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{start\PYGZus{}expr}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{n}{TO} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{end\PYGZus{}expr}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{STEP} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{step\PYGZus{}expr}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{p}{]}
    \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{statements}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}
\PYG{n}{NEXT}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
or (legacy synonym) \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ENDFOR}} in place of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NEXT}} (mapped internally).

\sphinxAtStartPar
Notes:
* Counter variable is (re)assigned the start value first.
* Step defaults to 1 or \sphinxhyphen{}1? (In classic PCBoard PPL: default is +1; negative requires explicit STEP \sphinxhyphen{}1.)
* Inclusive end bound (executes while counter \textless{}= end when step \textgreater{} 0, or \textgreater{}= end when step \textless{} 0).
* Modifying the loop variable inside the body is allowed but discouraged (can cause skipped termination).

\sphinxlineitem{GOTO (100+)}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Syntax: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{GOTO \textless{}label\textgreater{}}}
Transfers control unconditionally to a declared label (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{:\textless{}label\textgreater{}}} somewhere earlier or later).
Use sparingly; prefer structured constructs.

\sphinxlineitem{GOSUB (100+)}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Syntax: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{GOSUB \textless{}label\textgreater{}}}
Pushes return point and jumps to label. Return occurs when an implicit \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{RETURN}} or fall\sphinxhyphen{}through to end?
In modern Icy Board PPL you normally use PROCEDURE/FUNCTION; GOSUB is legacy support.

\sphinxlineitem{Labels (100+)}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Syntax: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{:\textless{}label\_name\textgreater{}}}
Declares a target for GOTO/GOSUB/BREAK label forms. Must be at statement start.
Case\sphinxhyphen{}insensitive. Decompiler emits uppercase or original style.

\sphinxlineitem{BREAK (100+; extended label form 350+)}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Syntax:}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Unlabeled: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{BREAK}} — exits innermost loop (WHILE / FOR / REPEAT / LOOP / SELECT inside loop).

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Labeled (350+): \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{BREAK :MyLabel}} — jumps out to label (decompiler may emit for structured transforms).

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\sphinxlineitem{CONTINUE (100+; labeled 350+)}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Syntax:}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{CONTINUE}} — skips to next iteration of current loop.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{CONTINUE :Label}} (350+) — advanced flow (rare; produced by transformations).

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\sphinxlineitem{RETURN (100+; inline expression 350+)}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Syntax (classic): \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{RETURN}}
Syntax (modern 350+): \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{RETURN \textless{}expr\textgreater{}}} inside a FUNCTION (or to exit PROCEDURE early ignoring value).
If legacy code assigns to the FUNCTION name and uses plain \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{RETURN}}, both styles coexist.

\end{description}


\subsubsection{Procedural \& Calls}
\label{\detokenize{ppl:procedural-calls}}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Procedure call (user\sphinxhyphen{}defined) (300+ for explicit PROCEDURE syntax; existed implicitly earlier)}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Syntax:}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
With arguments: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ProcName(arg1, arg2, ...)}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
No arguments: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ProcName}}

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Parentheses optional if no arguments (but recommended for clarity in modern code).

\sphinxlineitem{Predefined call (Built\sphinxhyphen{}in procedure statement) (100+)}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Examples: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{PRINT \textless{}expr\_list\textgreater{}}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{PRINTLN ...}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{BYE}}, file / user / message operations.
Grammar:
* Some accept argument lists separated by commas.
* See “Predefined Procedures” section (not duplicated here).

\sphinxlineitem{GOSUB / RETURN pair (legacy)}
\sphinxAtStartPar
See above under control flow. Consider rewriting heavy gosub usage into PROCEDURE/FUNCTION for clarity.

\end{description}


\subsubsection{Assignment \& Variables}
\label{\detokenize{ppl:assignment-variables}}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{LET / implicit LET (100+)}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Classic form allows optional \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LET}} keyword:

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LET Var = \textless{}expr\textgreater{}}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Var = \textless{}expr\textgreater{}}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Modern assignments (350+) support compound operators:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{=}} (assign)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{+=}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}=}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{*=}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{/=}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\%=}} (arithmetic)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\&=}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{|=}} (bitwise / logical according to operand types)

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Array / function\sphinxhyphen{}like indexing assignment:

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ArrayVar(i, j) = \textless{}expr\textgreater{}}}
(Parens style maintained for compatibility; some newer docs may show \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ArrayVar{[}i, j{]}}} when 400 object/index syntax fully stabilizes.)

\sphinxlineitem{Variable Declaration (typed) (300+)}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Syntax prototype:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{TYPE}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{n}{Var1}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{Var2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{Var3}\PYG{p}{]}
\PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{TYPE}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{n}{ArrayName}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{dim1}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{dim2}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{dim3}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Types (summary): BOOLEAN, INTEGER, UNSIGNED, BYTE, WORD, SBYTE, SWORD, MONEY, FLOAT, DOUBLE, STRING, BIGSTR, DATE, EDATE, TIME, DDATE, TABLE, MESSAGEAREAID, PASSWORD (plus future USERDATA objects 400+).

\sphinxAtStartPar
Declarations can appear at top level (global) or at start of procedure/function bodies.
(Versions \textless{}300 historically inferred variables on first assignment; modern compiler encourages explicit declarations for clarity and diagnostics.)

\end{description}


\subsubsection{Comments}
\label{\detokenize{ppl:comments}}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Single\sphinxhyphen{}line (100+)}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Semicolon: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{; This is a comment}} (preferred)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Apostrophe: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textquotesingle{} Also valid}} (legacy)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Leading \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{*}}: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{* Legacy style}} (still recognized for imported sources)

\end{itemize}

\sphinxlineitem{Block comments (350+ experimental)}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Parser supports multi\sphinxhyphen{}line block markers internally (emitted rarely by tools). Prefer single\sphinxhyphen{}line forms for portability.

\end{description}


\subsubsection{Miscellaneous}
\label{\detokenize{ppl:miscellaneous}}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{SELECT fall\sphinxhyphen{}through}
\sphinxAtStartPar
There is no implicit fall\sphinxhyphen{}through between CASE blocks; each CASE’s block executes fully then control jumps to ENDSELECT (unless \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{BREAK}} inside a nested loop is interpreted). Use multiple CASE value lists instead of stacked empty CASEs.

\sphinxlineitem{END (synthetic)}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The decompiler may show an internal \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{End}} comment or label transformation; you do not author a standalone \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{END}} statement in modern PPL (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ENDIF}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ENDWHILE}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ENDSELECT}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ENDLOOP}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NEXT}} serve as terminators).

\end{description}


\subsubsection{Deprecated / Discouraged Patterns}
\label{\detokenize{ppl:deprecated-discouraged-patterns}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Heavy \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{%
\PYG{k}{GOTO}%
}} / \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{%
\PYG{k}{GOSUB}%
}} chains \(\rightarrow\) replace with PROCEDURE / FUNCTION.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Relying on implicit variable creation (pre\sphinxhyphen{}300 era) \(\rightarrow\) add explicit declarations.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Using uppercase/lowercase inconsistently for labels \(\rightarrow\) labels are case\sphinxhyphen{}insensitive but pick one style (snake\_case or ALLCAPS).

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Modifying loop variables inside FOR other than via STEP semantics \(\rightarrow\) can create subtle off\sphinxhyphen{}by\sphinxhyphen{}one termination behavior.

\end{itemize}

\subsubsection{Examples}
\label{\detokenize{ppl:examples}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Single\sphinxhyphen{}line IF:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{IF} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{X} \PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{n}{PRINTLN} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}High\PYGZdq{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Block IF:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{IF} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{User}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{TimeLeft} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}} \PYG{l+m+mi}{5}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{THEN}
    \PYG{n}{PRINTLN} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}Time is low!\PYGZdq{}}
    \PYG{k}{GOTO} \PYG{n}{WarnLoop}
\PYG{k}{ELSEIF} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{User}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{TimeLeft} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{THEN}
    \PYG{n}{PRINTLN} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}Disconnecting soon...\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{k}{ELSE}
    \PYG{n}{PRINTLN} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}Plenty of time.\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{k}{ENDIF}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
FOR loop:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{FOR} \PYG{n}{I} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1} \PYG{n}{TO} \PYG{l+m+mi}{10}
    \PYG{n}{Total} \PYG{o}{+=} \PYG{n}{I}
\PYG{k}{NEXT}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
REPEAT / UNTIL:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{REPEAT}
    \PYG{n}{Line} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{INPUT}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{k}{UNTIL} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{Len}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{Line}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Compound assignment:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{BytesLeft} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}=} \PYG{n}{ChunkSize}
\PYG{n}{Flags} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}=} \PYG{err}{\PYGZti{}}\PYG{n}{FLAG\PYGZus{}NEW}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Procedure call:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{UpdateUserStats}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{UserId}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{TRUE}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Label / GOTO (legacy):

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{RetryLogin}
\PYG{k}{IF} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{Attempts} \PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{GOTO} \PYG{n}{Lockout}
\PYG{n}{PRINT} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}Password: \PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}
\PYG{k}{GOTO} \PYG{n}{RetryLogin}
\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{Lockout}
\PYG{n}{PRINTLN} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}Too many attempts.\PYGZdq{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Return with value (350+):

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{FUNCTION} \PYG{n}{Add}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{b}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k+kt}{INTEGER}
    \PYG{k}{RETURN} \PYG{n}{a} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n}{b}
\PYG{k}{ENDFUNC}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\subsubsection{EXIST (1.00)}
\label{\detokenize{ppl:exist-1-00}}\begin{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{%
\PYG{k}{FUNCTION} \PYG{k+kt}{BOOLEAN} \PYG{n+nb}{EXIST}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{k+kt}{STRING} \PYG{n}{file}\PYG{p}{)}%
}}
\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{\sphinxstylestrong{Parameters}}\begin{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{%
\PYG{n}{file}%
}} \textendash{} Path

\end{itemize}

\sphinxlineitem{\sphinxstylestrong{Returns}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
TRUE if file exists.

\end{description}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Example}
\begin{quote}

An integer indicating which operating system/PCBoard version the PPE is running under:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
0 = Unknown

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
1 = DOS/Windows

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
2 = OS/2 (legacy \sphinxhyphen{} unused)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
3 = Linux

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
4 = MacOS

\end{itemize}

\sphinxlineitem{\sphinxstylestrong{Description}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{%
\PYG{n}{OS}%
}} returns a value indicating the operating system environment.
In Icy Board, this currently returns 0 (unknown) as a placeholder for
compatibility. Legacy PPEs may use this to detect DOS vs OS/2 environments.

\sphinxlineitem{\sphinxstylestrong{Example}}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{SELECT} \PYG{k}{CASE} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{OS}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{k}{CASE} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}
        \PYG{n}{PRINTLN} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}Running on Icy Board or unknown system\PYGZdq{}}
    \PYG{k}{CASE} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}
        \PYG{n}{PRINTLN} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}Running DOS version of Icy Board\PYGZdq{}}
    \PYG{k}{CASE} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}
        \PYG{n}{PRINTLN} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}Running OS/2 version of Icy Board\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{n}{END} \PYG{k}{SELECT}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{%
\PYG{k}{FUNCTION} \PYG{k+kt}{STRING} \PYG{n+nb}{TINKEY}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{k+kt}{INTEGER} \PYG{n}{ticks}\PYG{p}{)}%
}}
\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{\sphinxstylestrong{Parameters}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{%
\PYG{n}{ticks}%
}} \textendash{} Maximum clock ticks to wait (\textasciitilde{}18 ticks per second).
Use 0 to wait indefinitely (implementation\textendash{}limited upper bound \textasciitilde{}4 hours or until carrier loss).

\end{itemize}

\sphinxlineitem{\sphinxstylestrong{Returns}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{%
\PYG{k+kt}{STRING}%
}} \textendash{} Key pressed (special names like UP / DOWN / PGUP) or empty string if timed out

\end{itemize}

\sphinxlineitem{\sphinxstylestrong{Description}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Waits for user input for up to the specified number of clock ticks.

\end{description}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Example}
\begin{quote}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kt}{STRING} \PYG{n}{resp}
\PYG{n}{PRINTLN} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}Press a key (10 second timeout)…\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{n}{resp} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb}{TINKEY}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{180}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{k}{IF} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{resp} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{THEN}
    \PYG{n}{PRINTLN} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}Timeout.\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{k}{ELSE}
    \PYG{n}{PRINTLN} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}You pressed: \PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{resp}
\PYG{k}{ENDIF}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\end{quote}
\end{quote}

\label{\detokenize{ppl:id5}}\begin{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar

\end{itemize}

\sphinxlineitem{\sphinxstylestrong{Returns}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
First matching filename (no path normalization) or empty string if none

\end{itemize}

\sphinxlineitem{\sphinxstylestrong{Description}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Begins a wildcard (pattern) scan. Use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{%
\PYG{n}{FINDNEXT}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}%
}} repeatedly to enumerate
additional matches. Only names are returned; use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{%
\PYG{n}{FILEINF}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}%
}} for metadata.

\end{description}

\sphinxAtStartPar

\PYG{k}{WHILE} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{toDelete} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{n}{DELETE} \PYG{n}{toDelete}
    \PYG{n}{PRINTLN} \PYG{n}{toDelete}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{} deleted.\PYGZdq{}}
    \PYG{n}{toDelete} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{FINDNEXT}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{k}{ENDWHILE}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\end{quote}

\PYG{n}{USELMRS} \PYG{n}{TRUE}
\PYG{n}{GETALTUSER} \PYG{l+m+mi}{300}
\PYG{n}{PRINTLN} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}Now LMRS for user 300 are loaded.\PYGZdq{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\end{quote}
\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{\sphinxstylestrong{Notes}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
